nodes.label: AI-based Bone Marrow Cell Differential Counting
nodes.summary: Development and validation of a machine learning algorithm using a Mask R-CNN model to automate the differential counting of nucleated cells in bone marrow aspiration smears.

nodes.label: Objective and Background
nodes.summary: To address the limitations of manual bone marrow cell counting by developing an automated, AI-based method for identifying and classifying cells.

nodes.label: Limitations of Manual Counting
nodes.summary: Manual differential counting is the current standard but is labor-intensive, time-consuming, and suffers from high interobserver variation and potential sampling bias.

nodes.label: Challenges in AI Model Development
nodes.summary: Key challenges include collecting sufficient high-quality data for diverse hematological disorders, non-routine digital image acquisition, and the time-consuming, technically demanding nature of expert annotation.

nodes.label: Methodology
nodes.summary: An AI model was trained using a large, expert-annotated dataset of bone marrow smear images from multiple institutions.

nodes.label: AI Model
nodes.summary: A Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Mask R-CNN) was used to simultaneously detect and classify individual bone marrow cells.

nodes.label: Training Dataset
nodes.summary: The model was trained on a dataset of 542 slides containing 597,222 annotated cells.

nodes.label: Staining Methods
nodes.summary: The slides were stained with Liu’s stain (85.1%) and Wright–Giemsa stain (14.9%).

nodes.label: Annotation Process
nodes.summary: Experts from different institutes held consensus meetings to ensure consistent cell classification criteria.

nodes.label: Performance and Validation
nodes.summary: The AI model's performance was evaluated on an initial testing set and then validated on a larger, multinational real-world dataset.

nodes.label: Initial Testing Results
nodes.summary: The model achieved an accuracy of 0.94 on a testing dataset containing 26,170 cells.

nodes.label: Multinational Validation Results
nodes.summary: Validation was performed on a real-world dataset of 200,639 cells from four centers in Taiwan and the US.

nodes.label: Overall Accuracy
nodes.summary: The model achieved an accuracy of 0.881 in classifying individual cells.

nodes.label: Cell-Specific Precision
nodes.summary: Demonstrated high precision for key cell types: Blasts (0.927), Bands and PMNs (0.955), Plasma cells (0.930), and Lymphocytes (0.789).

nodes.label: Correlation with Manual Method
nodes.summary: A strong correlation (ρ > 0.8) was observed between AI and manual differential counting percentages for most cell categories.

nodes.label: Conclusion
nodes.summary: The developed AI algorithm was clinically validated using large, multinational datasets, demonstrating its potential for automating bone marrow differential counting in clinical practice.
